Title: Music Review: On Addison Raeâ€™s â€˜Addison,â€™ a new pop powerhouse is born
Paragraphs: ['', 'NEW YORK (AP) â€” The pop album of the summer is here. Addison Raeâ€™s debut, â€œAddison,â€ is full, stuffed with bejeweled, hypnotic pop songs for the post-â€œBRATâ€ crowd. Hedonism has a new hero.', 'For those whoâ€™ve watched her rise, itâ€™s almost impossible to believe. It wasnâ€™t so long ago â€“ almost exactly a year into the COVID-19 pandemic â€“ that a young Rae went on â€œThe Tonight Showâ€ and taught its host Jimmy Fallon a few stiff, meme-able TikTok dance moves, then what made up the bulk of her career. It was met with almost immediate backlash, as is common for young women with viral posts. But she wielded it like a weapon: Social media celebrity begat acting roles for Rae, then a coveted collaboration with Charli XCX in the form of a â€œVon Dutchâ€ remix, and now, at age 24, her final form: becoming the hyper-ambitious, hyper-femme pop star for the current moment.', 'As a full body of work, â€œAddisonâ€ taps into the genre-agnostic zeitgeist, where pop music appears edgy and elastic. The songs speak for themselves, from the pitch-shifted trip-hop â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and the snapped percussion, minor chords, NSFW lyrics and vanishing synths of â€œHigh Fashionâ€ to the Madonnaâ€œRay of Lightâ€-cosplay â€œAquamarineâ€ atop a house beat and its chantable, spoken chorus: â€œThe world is my oyster / Baby, come touch the pearl / The world is my oyster / And Iâ€™m the only girl.â€', 'Humor and girlhood are intertwined with less of a Sabrina Carpenter-wink and more of cheery irony. â€œMoney loves me,â€ she yells on â€œMoney Is Everything.â€ â€œIâ€™m the richest girl in the world!â€ Then, a giggle and a kiss. (â€œGirl,â€ to this writerâ€™s count, is uttered 20 times across the album. Across its 12 tracks, she is both the divine feminine and the girl next door. Often, they are one in the same.)', 'Rae isnâ€™t reinventing the wheel here, but she is carefully pulling from her inspirations. Her story recalls Britney Spears: The pair are from Louisiana, became famous young, and recorded their unique, sensual, layered pop music in Stockholm, Sweden, in and around super producer Max Martin. Thereâ€™s the earned Lana Del Rey parity, like in the â€œBorn to Dieâ€-channeling â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ echoes of Charli in the bouncy opener â€œNew York,â€ and tinges of ethereal Enya production on the dreamy â€œSummer Forever.â€', 'For â€œAddison,â€ Rae partnered with two primary collaborators â€“ Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd, who goes simply by Elvira â€“ an unusually small team for a major label pop release. But that intimacy is one of the albumâ€™s superpowers, a sensibility that teeters between close mic recordings and big late-night anthems. In the latter case, look no further than â€œFame Is a Gun,â€ an easy song-of-the-summer contender, a sunglasses-in-the-club banger with synthetic vocal textures and an unignorable chorus.', 'In the lead up to the release of â€œAddison,â€ Rae has positioned her early TikTok fame as a means to an end. There arenâ€™t many avenues to Hollywood from Lafayette, Louisiana, and social media, for some, is a democratizing tool. Rae used her dance training to build a name for herself on the platform, something that has no doubt laid an ideal foundation for pop superstardom â€“ just consider how Justin Bieber did something similar with covers on YouTube not so many years ago. It feels full circle, then, that Raeâ€™s stellar debut album aims to do what her videos on TikTok attempted to do, what sheâ€™s always wanted to do â€” dance, and get others to dance, too.', '', 'Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. Title: Addison Rae just released her debut studio album, solidifying her status as pop musicâ€™s latest â€˜itâ€™ girl
Paragraphs: ['', '', '', '', '', 'Addison Rae is ready to reintroduce herself.', 'Since amassing more than 88 million followers on TikTok, the 24-year-old has effectively pivoted her career from social media influencer to full-blown pop girl â€” and her self-titled, debut studio album, Addison, released on June 6, is proof of that. Rae, a former cheerleader from Louisiana, is living out her nostalgic "noughties" dream â€” and sheâ€™s making music that captures that feeling.', 'On Addison, Rae serves up her now signature trip-hop meets synth-pop sound. â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ Raeâ€™s first release since 2021â€™s â€œObsessed,â€ marked a turning point in the young starâ€™s career: It showcased Raeâ€™s artistry at its most sophisticated. Addisonâ€™s 12-song tracklist, through its exploration of fantasy, fearlessness and doing what feels good and right for you, solidifies Rae as both a student of pop divas past and the genreâ€™s latest â€œitâ€ girl.', 'â€œâ€˜Addisonâ€™ is out now and alive everywhere in the universe for you to receiveeeeeee!!! This is my most personal and intimate possession,â€ she captioned an Instagram post. â€œMaking music is vulnerable, energetically sensitive, electric, gratifying, challengingâ€¦â€¦ pure magic. I am unbelievably proud.â€', 'At midnight on album release day, Rae debuted her sixth single along with the songâ€™s accompanying music video. Showcasing Rae at her most vulnerable, â€œTimes Like These,â€ which delves into her past and current tribulations, sounds like something youâ€™d hear in a Josh Schwartz teen drama from the 2000s.', 'Hours before Addison hit streamers, Rae performed a private show at the Box in New York City, where she played the albumâ€™s singles and previewed some previously unreleased tracks. She then stopped by a Matchaful to unveil her limited edition â€œSummer Foreverâ€ drink with the cafÃ©.', 'Early listeners have spoken: The album is filled with bangers.', 'â€œThe very fact that addison rae just released a skipless debut album and managed to carve out a signature sound and artistic niche for herself in the oversaturated climate of todayâ€™s music market,â€ one fan named Vidya wrote on X.', 'â€œImagine I just told you that there was a female pop album that just dropped, that talks about familial love, the general angst and confusion you feel in your twenties and radical acceptance, and did it in a way that was really artistically intelligent,â€ a TikTok user named Sam said. â€œNow, imagine I just told you that was Addison Rae.â€', 'Another X user raved about Raeâ€™s song â€œNew York,â€ writing, â€œobsessed with everything about this track. her starting her debut album with the phrase â€˜take a bite of the big apple,â€™ not only referencing new york but also adam and eve and the beginning of human civilization.. like thereâ€™s LAYERSSS. addison rae you are a genius.â€', 'In an interview with Zane Lowe for Apple Music 1, Rae discussed how precious Addison is to her, and how she wants to give the album its moment.', 'â€œI think Iâ€™m in the space right now where Iâ€™m just really anticipating it coming out, and Iâ€™m like, trying to hit all the stops,â€ she said ahead of its debut. â€œAnd even with posting and feeling like, â€˜Okay, well, I really want to make sure I give this the credit and the energy that it deserves.â€™ I think sometimes I shy away from that because Iâ€™ll be like â€¦ â€˜Is it going to be too much if Iâ€™m just like, â€˜Alright, everybody! The albumâ€™s this many days awayâ€™ â€¦ Sometimes I get onto myself about that and Iâ€™ll be like, â€˜No, it deserves that.â€™â€', 'Focusing on her passions was more of a risk than a given.', 'â€œI just had this really strong intuition and gut feeling that, as unrealistic as it seemed, I needed to do it â€” thereâ€™s no time like now to try and chase those dreams,â€ she told Elle earlier this year of her decision to pursue music.', 'The pursuit of those dreams seems to have paid off. Long before she was lauded as a pop princess, Rae was a mainstay on the video-sharing platform, TikTok.', 'The Louisiana native first joined the app in July 2019, where she posted a slew of content that ranged from TikTok challenges to dancing and lip-synching videos. She racked up a million followers within a matter of months and made the decision to leave Louisiana State University shortly after. The rest, as they say, is history. Rae made her film debut with 2021â€™s Heâ€™s All That, the same year she released â€œObsessed.â€ She starred in the horror flick Thanksgiving in 2023, three months after dropping her EP AR, which features the Charli XCX-assisted track â€œ2 Die 4.â€', 'The release of Addison comes a year after Rae famously collaborated with Charli on the â€œVon Dutchâ€ remix. From there, she went on to garner widespread acclaim with the debut of her first major single â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ a hypnotic, synth-pop track about young lust, in August 2024. The songâ€™s release was accompanied by a black-and-white video conceptualized by Rae herself.', 'â€œI think even going [and] watching old movies, and appreciating them for what they are, and how strongly you had to communicate through a black-and-white video, for people to take their time and watch it,â€ Rae told Lowe of making the video. â€œAnd I think the song deserves that treatment of like, â€˜I get it. Youâ€™re gonna have to focus really hard on it,â€™ but I want you to have to focus really hard on it to get it.â€', 'Suddenly, after â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ it felt as though Rae was inescapable. She joined Charli onstage during her â€œSweat Tourâ€ stop at New York Cityâ€™s Madison Square Garden that September before dropping â€œAquamarine,â€ her single about transformation and rebirth, in October, followed by its remix â€œAquamarine/Arcamarineâ€ in November.', 'Rae ushered in the new year with the release of her third single off the album â€œHigh Fashionâ€ in February 2025. On the track, Rae sees no appeal in embarking on a drug-fueled bender and instead opts for the finer things in life: a closet full of couture. She sings, with her soft, atmospheric vocals atop a darker, synthier sound, â€œI donâ€™t need your drugs/Iâ€™d rather get high fashion.â€', 'After gracing the cover of Vogue France, the singer dropped her fourth single in April 2025. With â€œHeadphones On,â€ Rae gives listeners a peek into how she relies on music as an escape from crisis and reality. The 24-year-old singer then reunited with Charli XCX at Coachella, where she performed the â€œVon Dutchâ€ remix.', 'â€œFame Is a Gun,â€ Raeâ€™s fifth and final single â€” and music video â€” ahead of album release day, hit streaming platforms in May 2025. The trackâ€™s artwork is a photo of a young Rae posing with sunglasses indoors, likely a nod to the fact that Rae has always been drawn to living a glamorous life.', 'Raeâ€™s album, more than anything, is about arrival.', 'â€œItâ€™s arrival to who I feel like Iâ€™ve become,â€ she told Lowe. â€œIâ€™ve experienced all these trials and ups and downs, and great high moments to land here.â€', 'Whether youâ€™re a fan of Rae or a fan of music in general, Addison reflects an undeniable truth: Weâ€™re watching an artist come into her own before our eyes.']

Title: The Emancipation of Addison Rae
Paragraphs: ['', '', '', 'The influencer pop sphere is, mathematically, a graveyard with more misfires than successful conversions of internet cachet into hit parades. The same machine that helped Troye Sivan and Benson Boone evolve also yields terrible singles by controversial beauty-industry personality James Charles. When TikTok star Addison Rae first dipped her toe into pop in 2021, she seemed destined for the latter bucket. Her first single, â€œ,â€ didnâ€™t register as the satire she intended, as people assumed the dancer, now suddenly a singer, was deeply conceited. But in pop, with the right ideas and co-signs, the bubbliness and determination people came to resent in Raeâ€™s TikTok demeanor are common currency. On her 2023 EP, she worked with up to five co-writers per song and producers who bathed her wispy, inviting voice in familiar dance-pop tropes. Its bops quietly succeeded where Raeâ€™s dalliances in makeup and movies floundered. She has spent the interim workshopping a sound worthy of words of encouragement from Charli XCX and Ariana Grande.', 'Her debut album, Addison, doesnâ€™t seek simple portfolio diversification. It stages a symbolic break with the past. This is her thing now. Sheâ€™s dropping the Rae, her middle name. Her parents, frequent fixtures in her early content but more recently in tales of gallivanting with 20-somethings, are notably silent. Addison documents a 24-year-old budding artist coolly working out what even to sing and write about. Unlike her EP, the album is the work of merely three composers: Addison and Max Martin affiliates Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd. Itâ€™s refreshing and light not just thanks to the sunny, southern ersatz-cheerleader disposition that made Addison famous but also to three young womenâ€™s trust and relative freedom from industry veteransâ€™ nagging, predictable oversight.', 'Addison is a high-stakes show of being low-key. Its lyrics revel in agency and possibilities, landing like metatextual reflections on Addisonâ€™s overarching professional pivot. â€œAquamarine,â€ a Europop thumper, sounds like sultry Madonna fan service. But beyond the Ray of Light reference, thereâ€™s a sense that the hook â€” â€œHoney, dive into me / Iâ€™m not hiding anymoreâ€ â€” addresses a question that has nagged her career so far: What emotional depth is there to be found in the work? The maudlin â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ opens by mulling over outfits that would titillate a partner, but it turns into a venting session about being perceived by millions; her songâ€™s on the radio, she sings, but she worries about the velocity of her life ramping up where others celebrate. The writing is all very slight, but the gains over earlier outings are felt in songs like â€œMoney Is Everything,â€ a trap-pop spend-it-if-you-got-it jam. â€œMoneyâ€ gets close to the concept of â€œObsessed.â€ Here, melodrama and misandry merge in lyrics and a performance drenched in the giddiest disbelief about smoking weed with Lady Gaga. pushes to take itself less seriously, a wise adjustment for the singer famously roasted in 2020 for refusing to stop recording herself to greet her fans. The best songs paint vibrantly on a relatively blank musical slate; the others chase prefabricated styles.', 'The parallels to Britney Spears are loud. Both Louisiana singers luxuriate at the point where a whisper becomes a coo; both have crafted gossamer pop with Swedish producers. The blonde-bombshell bedlam in â€™s â€œFame Is a Gunâ€ video resembles the behind-the-scenes drama and starry blue wallpaper of â€œLucky,â€ while â€œIn the Rainâ€ conjures the drum-heavy hip-pop of Britneyâ€™s Neptunes collaborations. (A notable difference is that the teenage Spears was not in control of these concepts the way Addison expresses a take-charge approach to her art and image.) Elsewhere, â€œSummer Foreverâ€ and â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ bask in the heavy reverb and anesthetized upper-register sigh of Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œBlue Jeansâ€ and â€œSummertime Sadness.â€ These songs fall back on Rae-era propensities, flexing the internet personalityâ€™s instinct for a cresting trend but failing to do better than the real Lana songs and knockoffs flooding the market. They abandon the mission of creating some distance between this pop iteration and the Addison who blew up doing lip syncs. More enticing are the songs angling to eke out an insistent literary voice and impactful but playful sonic imprint.', 'Even when a lyric can use more time in the oven â€” take â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ waving off Addisonâ€™s anxiety with a humdrum refrain of â€œIn times like these itâ€™s, itâ€™s how it has to be,â€ or the vague â€œLifeâ€™s no fun through clear watersâ€ line in â€œHeadphones Onâ€ â€” it feels bespoke. Wrapped up in the appeal of TikTok is the idea that everyone is one consequential view away from fame. Addison found her creative bearings in the incentivized piggybacking of this maelstrom. Escaping means finding out and sharing with the world what sheâ€™s really like and not just highlighting things she enjoys that she hopes you will, too, as influencers do so well. Sheâ€™s not trying to write herself into autoplaying after the Spotify chart toppers in â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ or â€œHeadphones On.â€ Sheâ€™s looking for language that speaks colorfully to a unique status as a newly recertified It Girl. â€œFameâ€ and â€œHigh Fashionâ€ have a blast with being an internet punching bag, the former sneering about how little Addison has to do to generate negative press and the latter joking that she cares more about shoes than you. â€œWhen you shade me,â€ â€œFameâ€ admits, â€œit makes me want it more.â€', 'Itâ€™s like she got dragged just enough to know not to come on too intensely, except where thereâ€™s humor to be wrung from embodying the vapid L.A.-to-LA gloryseeker we had her pegged as. Addison has always wanted in on her own joke, and the album delivers a few of the funniest attacks on her old shtick in the name of building a new persona from those foundations. She cusses and smokes and gets that, not so long ago, people didnâ€™t think so much of her. Addison finds that emancipatory. Thereâ€™s no library of expectations yet. Each single hit like a pleasant shock, and the album succeeds in advancing their agenda of upending any lingering feeling that Addisonâ€™s mostly good for an eight-count and a smile. If she wants to push herself as a writer, getting deeper than just wishing her parents hadnâ€™t gotten divorced, and maybe interrogating the finer quirks of parasocial relationships between audiences and personalities, the road to a sustained pop tenure is open. If she doesnâ€™t care to do any of that, then is something cool for the summer.', 'Already a subscriber? Sign in', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

Title: Every Thought We Had Listening to Addison Raeâ€™s Debut Album, Addison
Paragraphs: ['', '', '', 'Last August, Addison Rae did something unexpected. She released a breathy, slinky song near the tail end of Brat summer and propelled herself into the mainstream music scene. Everywhere you went, â€œâ€was on. A few weeks later, she at their sold-out Madison Square Garden Sweat tour stop to perform it live for the first time (it made me cry! For real!). The former TikTok star who rose to popularity with her dance videos had broken the code. She released a hit.', 'What followed was a rebrand of sorts. She was featured on a Charli XCX remix, took the stage with Arca at Coachella, and continued to release singles, alongside high-concept music videos, throughout the year to prepare fans for her self-titled debut-album release. I would argue the 24-year-old used the past year to find her footing â€” but do we know her any better? Even after listening to 33 minutes of Addison, weâ€™re not too sure. Nonetheless, we had to commemorate the moment by listening to the album first thing this morning and talking about it with one another on Slack. Hereâ€™s what the Cut team thought.', 'Brooke LaMantia, editorial assistant: What are everyoneâ€™s initial thoughts on the album?', 'Julia Reinstein, morning blogger: Opening with â€œNew Yorkâ€ is so good. I am floating!', 'Bianca Nieves, senior shopping editor: â€œNew Yorkâ€ is her â€œParty in the U.S.A.â€ It was a strong start, but then I got a bit bored.', 'Emily Leibert, writer: Aside from the singles she released (and there were too many, in my opinion), it has a 2000s Whoa, Nelly! lying-in-the-grass sound.', 'Brooke L.: It did feel like I had listened to half the album already.', 'Emily L: Of the new songs on the album, â€œSummer Foreverâ€ and â€œIn the Rainâ€ are my favorites, but they do not hold a motherfucking candle to â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ or â€œFame Is a Gun.â€ Dreamy lyrics, naked-on-the-beach vibes, pop girl from Louisiana â€¦ I get it.', 'Brooke Marine, deputy culture editor: â€œIn the Rainâ€ feels like a Janet-type beat. Iâ€™m into it.', 'Julia R.: My hot take is I want Addison and Miley Cyrus to collaborate. My other hot take is I want Miley, Addison, and Ethel Cain to collaborate. They are all doing cool ambient shit! We need .', 'Emily L.: Iâ€™m also obsessed that Addisonâ€™s idea of New York is so generic. Bowery hotel! The people are free!', 'Jordan Larson, features editor: I just hear Charli XCX when I listen to â€œNew York.â€ Except slow, like she took too much K.', 'Emily L.: If â€œNew Yorkâ€ is the K, â€œLost & Foundâ€ is the K-hole.', 'Bianca N.: I think she was trying to give Tumblr and landed in WeHeartIt, which is just as iconic but not the same. It goes more with her album art, too.', 'Brook L.: Do we feel like this was authentic to Addison? Do we understand who she is now?', 'Emily L.: I think her creative team did an incredible job of curating a neon-pink, sepia-toned, photos-on-film aesthetic of an album. Do we know Addison any better because of it? I donâ€™t think so. This feels like a sonic mood board, not a cohesive statement about an artist.', 'Julia R.: She is unknowable, and I am okay with it.', 'Brooke L.: I mean, she is 24. â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ felt like the most weâ€™ve learned about her even though they were pretty generic feelings, like â€œIâ€™m so confusedâ€ on a loop. Which, fair.', 'Emily L.: The things I know about Addison at this point are she likes making out in the car, she likes when her lips reflect off his cross gold chain, and she likes crying in the rain.', 'Brooke L: What music video are we most excited for? I canâ€™t wait to see â€œNew Yorkâ€ through her lens.', 'Julia R.: Sheâ€™s already put out so many videos! Like half of this album was already a single. But yes, â€œNew Yorkâ€ is the answer.', 'Emily L.:  I want to see her go to Basement. Or send her to the unfinished Brooklyn Mirage in a hard hat.', 'Julia R.: â€œWho Will Addison Rae Endorse in the New York Mayoral?â€', 'Brooke L.: She can use the video to canvass for Zohran.', 'Emily L.: I want to give â€œMoney Is Everything,â€ â€œTimes Like These,â€ and â€œLifeâ€™s No Fun Through Clear Watersâ€ some time to simmer in my brain. If I give them enough airtime, Iâ€™ll probably end up liking them unironically. And I do like her unironically, as you all know.', 'Julia R.: I have been an unironic fan since â€œ2 Die 4.â€', 'Brooke L.: Last question: Is Addison giving us the opulence of girlhood, as other interviews have said?', 'Julia R.: â€œOpulence of girlhoodâ€? I donâ€™t think so. It all has a vague sadness about it.', 'Emily L.: Her â€œopulenceâ€ doesnâ€™t exist without the messiness of being a young woman. Itâ€™s pearls and flash photography but also powdered-sugar snow angels and rage screams.', 'Brooke L.: Itâ€™s modern girlhood.', 'Julia R.: Itâ€™s wearing perfume but also being a little smelly.', 'Emily L.: Just a hint of B.O. Title: EVERY IT GIRL MENTIONED IN ADDISON
Paragraphs: ['MUSIC', 'The higher the reference rate, the closer to pop stardom.', 'The day has come: Addison Raeâ€™s debut album, Addison, has finally arrived. Just like â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ â€œHeadphones On,â€ and â€œFame Is A Gunâ€ led us to believe, the project features a vibrant-yet-moody collection of songs that name Raeâ€™s foremothers in pop music.', 'Raeâ€™s references are more than just sonic, however, as the singer also pays tribute to some of the most iconic It girls of yore on â€œMoney Is Everything.â€ In the song, she singles out four pop-culture icons who defined their respective generations while highlighting her not-so-subtle aspirations to do the same.', 'MADONNA', 'In the first (and only) verse, Rae sings, â€œI drink on the nights that I want to remember / And when Iâ€™m out dancing / Please DJ play Madonna.â€ The line not only expresses Raeâ€™s desire to hang out with the Queen of Pop herself, but doubles as a reference to the Madonna track â€œMusic,â€ which opens with a request for the DJ to â€œput a record on.â€', 'As a whole, the track simultaneously serves as an ode to the finer things in life Ã  la Madgeâ€™s â€œMaterial Girl.â€ Rae giggles at the thought of making money before musing on the possibility that it can, in fact, buy happiness. â€œWhen I was growing up / Momma always told me to save my money / So I never had to rely on a man to take care of me / But moneyâ€™s not coming with me to heaven and I have a lot of it / So canâ€™t a girl just have fun?,â€ she wonders. By the end of the track, sheâ€™s practically screaming about how much money loves her. â€œIâ€™m the richest girl in the world,â€ she declares.', 'LANA DEL REY', 'Rae also calls out Lana Del Rey in the following line, â€œWanna roll one with Lana.â€ As a longtime fan (the 24-year-old has been lip-syncing to Reyâ€™s videos since her TikTok days), Rae doesnâ€™t just aspire to partake in a smoke sesh with the â€œHigh By The Beachâ€ singer â€” she wants to be on a first-name basis with the artist. This becomes especially clear in the final line of the verse, â€œAnd the girl I used to be is still the girl inside of me,â€ as Rae hints at an inability to silence her inner fangirl.', 'LADY GAGA', 'Rae follows up the Lana lyric with a line about wanting to â€œGet high with Gaga,â€ which could read as a desire to be on Gagaâ€™s level creatively, artistically, and, yes, even financially.', 'MARILYN MONROE', 'Embedded in the chorus is the final tribute to the original It girl, Marilyn Monroe. Though Rae doesnâ€™t actually utter the name on the album, she does call out Monroe by her birth name, Norma Jeane. â€œDiamonds are my best friend / Like Iâ€™m Norma Jeane,â€ she sings, referencing Monroeâ€™s performance of â€œDiamonds Are A Girlâ€™s Best Friendâ€ in the 1949 film, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes â€” the very same movie recreated in Madonnaâ€™s â€œMaterial Girlâ€ music video.']

Title: The kaleidoscopic pastiche of Addison Raeâ€™s arrival
Paragraphs: ['Date:', 'Who could have predicted that Addison Rae, the queen of pandemic-era TikTok and subject of one of the internetâ€™s most memorable cringe-fuelled videos, would emerge as the preeminent rising pop diva of 2025? But sure enough, Rae has arrived in every sense of the word. In the era of unerasable digital footprints, she has accomplished the impressive feat of transitioning from social media starlet to serious pop superstar â€” and has done so with relative seamlessness. Her full-length debut Addison, out today, is a bite-sized pastiche of bubbling, kaleidoscopic pop that whirs, purrs and aggregates moods, images, and feelings with ease. Rather than teetering into obvious copy-paste territory, the album succeeds in the spaces in between its references, in effect delivering something that feels both familiar yet fresh. ', 'But five years after her name entered the pop culture lexicon, who is Addison Rae? In some corners of the internet, she is a master of pop cultural propaganda with a talent for convincing the masses of her artistic merits. If you were to ask Rae herself, sheâ€™d likely say that sheâ€™s just a Southern girl whoâ€™s always had dreams of making it big in entertainment. She also might say that the Addison Rae of today is who sheâ€™s been all along. As she told Interview Magazine last summer, â€œGirl, nobodyâ€™s rebranding. This is me.â€ More recently on the New York Times Popcast, sheâ€™s claimed that her TikTok grind was never the goal, but was merely a way for her to gain enough exposure to achieve her entertainment dreams. Itâ€™s often said that the truth lies in the middle of two sides of a story, and itâ€™s safe to assume that this notion applies to Rae. Propaganda master or not, her music is good enough to speak on its own. ', 'Across 10 full-length songs and two interludes, Rae navigates sharp thematic and sonic turns with admirable agility. She bounces from languid lust (â€œDiet Pepsiâ€) to cheeky sarcasm (â€œMoney is Everythingâ€), creating pendulum swings that keep the listener engaged without pause for the albumâ€™s 33 minute duration. From the first thud of album opener â€œNew York,â€ which bounces off the eardrum superbly, to the seductive slink of â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and â€œTimes Like These,â€ itâ€™s evident that Rae is a dedicated student of pop (as all aspiring pop stars should be). She fluctuates from loose Lana Del Rey-esque gloom (â€œDiet Pepsiâ€) to a closing three-track run that invokes touches of soulful â€˜90s house and R&B. â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ and â€œHeadphones Onâ€ land somewhere in between the warm, R&B sounds of Madonnaâ€™s Bedtime Stories and the cooler, cinematic electronic landscape of Ray of Light. But Raeâ€™s allusions to her pop foremothers manage to come off in a way that evades blatant duplication, and instead land as earnest homages. ', 'The recordâ€™s production cocoons Raeâ€™s lyrical efforts that may occasionally land slightly off kilter, but are even more often undeniably fun. Lines like, â€œwhen Iâ€™m up dancing, please, DJ, play Madonna/Wanna roll one with Lana, get high with Gaga,â€ jump out upon first listen but capture Rae unabashedly exploring her craft instead of grasping at lyrical straws. ', '', 'But among all of the albumâ€™s delicious references and quirky admissions, itâ€™s Raeâ€™s hunger that is the biggest treat to hear. On one of the recordâ€™s greatest feats,â€œFame is a Gun,â€ a bubbling pop bounce seasoned with glitchy inflections, she makes her ambitions clear. As she sings on the second verse, â€œThereâ€™s no mystery, Iâ€™m gonna make it, gonna go down in history/Donâ€™t ask too many questions, God gave me the permission/And when you shame me, it makes me want it more.â€ Moments like these, when she breaks the fourth wall and plays into the narrative of how badly she wants to make it, add a piece to the puzzle of her persona, and in retrospect make all of the paparazzi stunts and creative COVID-19 masks make sense. If nothing else, the girl knows how to keep people talking â€” and isnâ€™t that all you need to launch a pop career these days?  ', 'Raeâ€™s earnestness is no doubt a key part of whatâ€™s gotten her to this point. How can you not take fondly to a 24-year-old girl from Louisiana with unmistakable Southern charm not far off from fellow Lousianan Britney Spears? Where other current pop girls have taken the same approach of packaging collected aesthetics and sounds into their own (recent memory calls back to Camila Cabelloâ€™s C,XOXO), the difference is that Raeâ€™s pursuit of popâ€™s top tier isnâ€™t a hard sell. Whether it be a genius creative team behind her or that indescribable â€œitâ€ factor driving her smooth transition into the big leagues of pop, itâ€™s safe to say sheâ€™s pulling it off. Put plainly, she makes it look easy.', 'In a discussion earlier this year about Raeâ€™s pursuit of fame and creative worthiness, a friend of mine put it plainly: â€œat least you can tell she wants it.â€ And really, what more can we ask of our pop stars than to want it?', 'Keep up with Addison Rae: Instagram // TikTok // YouTube // Website', '', '', '', '', 'SHARE POST:', 'More from Author', 'Independent and fueled by love and dedication. Title: Addison Rae Is Here to Stay: Inside Her Album Release Party at NYCâ€™s The Box
Paragraphs: ['The singer celebrated the release of her first full-length effort with a euphoric live concert produced in partnership with Spotify', "Every product on this page was chosen by a Harper's BAZAAR editor. We may earn commission on some of the items you choose to buy.", 'Late on a Thursday evening in a burlesque-inspired nightclub called The Box, a gaggle of gays and girls gathered to see Addison Rae perform songs from her debut album, Addison, live for the first time.', 'Co-hosted by Spotify, the event was simultaneously understated and fabulousâ€”a perfect representation for Addison (who recently proclaimed that she wants to drop â€œRaeâ€) as an artist. Acrobatic dancers hung from the ceiling and waiters walked around with platters of tuna tartare, while at the same time, attendees sipped from â€œDiet Pepsiâ€-inspired cocktails and plastered glitter and stick-on gems onto their faces. It was like getting ready for a rave in your friendâ€™s bedroom, but that bedroom happened to be an exclusive New York City nightclub.', 'Itâ€™s not often that a pop star generates this much excitement before their debut album even drops. In the past few years, weâ€™ve been spoiled with so much new young talent, from Olivia Rodrigo to Chappell Roan and Sabrina Carpenter. You would think that there might not be space for another voice to break through. But like how Lindsay Lohan managed to crack her Spring Fling crown into enough pieces for her classmates in Mean Girls, the pop royalty crown is always big enough to welcome newcomers when a worthy voice rises up.', 'Before she was singing in front of cheering crowds, Addison famously got her start on TikTok, where she quickly became one of the most-followed figures on the app, thanks to her dance videos. Her popularity ultimately inspired her to drop out of college and sign with a talent agency in 2020â€”then came the podcasts, acting opportunities, and high-profile appearances on late night talk shows.', 'Her first foray into music was with her 2021 single â€œObsessed,â€ which was released to mostly unfavorable reviews. â€œI felt a little beaten down,â€ Addison said in an interview with The New York Timesâ€™s Popcast last month. â€œI was like, â€˜Oh wait, I canâ€™t just have fun and explore. People are not gonna allow that. I have too many people giving an opinion on this for it to be as free as I want it to be.â€™ It definitely hurt. I kept writing though.â€', 'After a somewhat clumsy but inoffensive start, Addison knew she needed to come back stronger. Two years later, she dropped the EP AR, which featured infectious bubblegum hits like â€œI Got It Badâ€ and a cover of the unreleased Lady Gaga song â€œNothing On (But the Radio).â€ Proving she had the chops and the starry friends to back them up, Addison even recruited Charli XCX to feature on the song â€œ2 Die 4â€ (a year before brat summer took over the cultural zeitgeist).', 'Then, Addison took it up another level when she released the first single from her debut album, called â€œDiet Pepsi.â€ The moody, sensual track became her first song to chart on the Billboard Hot 100, and it was named one of the best tracks of 2024 by outlets like Pitchfork, Billboard, Rolling Stone, and more. In the months following, Addison kept the momentum going by releasing a string of equally compelling and progressively kooky singles: â€œAquamarineâ€; â€œHigh Fashionâ€; â€œHeadphones Onâ€; â€œFame Is a Gun.â€', 'All of this buildup came to a peak on Thursday evening, when the singer stepped out for a mini show in front of fans and fellow artists who came to support, like Clairo and Conan Gray. Throughout her seven-song set, Addison sang her string of singles, while debuting two as-yet unreleased ones, all the while doing multiple outfit changes, dancing through intimate set designs, and commanding the audience with ease. Fans screamed along to the lyrics and filmed with their phonesâ€”often shakily as they were too busy dancing along to the tracks. The show was sweaty, silly, and euphoric. And if there was one thing I couldnâ€™t stop thinking throughout it, it was: The next big pop star has been born.', 'By the time I left, the clock had already struck midnight, meaning Addison was out for the rest of the world to hear. I immediately put my headphones on and started listening. I listened multiple times, in fact, before I went to bed, and Iâ€™ve had it on repeat in the hours since. Itâ€™s hypnotizing and intriguing. Some of the songs feel simple, but the more you sit with them, you realize theyâ€™re so smart. Itâ€™s funny, emotional, and romantic. I donâ€™t mean this lightly when I say: Itâ€™s one of the best opening statements Iâ€™ve heard from a pop star in years. Ahead, I share my five biggest takeaways.', '', 'If thereâ€™s one thing that the biggest pop girls of today posses, itâ€™s a good sense of humor. And like Sabrina, Chappell, and Charli, Addison is unafraid to imbue a bit of comedy into her songs. Weâ€™ve already seen her ability to turn a cheeky phrase thanks to the single â€œHigh Fashion,â€ where Rae claims that she doesnâ€™t need drugs, sheâ€™d rather â€œget high fashion.â€ But some of the newly-unveiled tracks are especially funny, like â€œMoney Is Everything,â€ where Rae opens the song with a spoken word intro like something youâ€™d hear on an early Britney track: â€œWhen I was growing up / Mama always told me to save my money / So I never had to rely on a man to take care of me / But moneyâ€™s not coming with me to heaven / And I have a lot of it / So canâ€™t a girl just have fun?â€ Even some of the more somber songs have a tinge of humor to them, like â€œIn the Rain,â€ where Rae dramatically claims that she only cries in storms, seemingly so that she can mask her tears.', 'In â€œFame Is a Gun,â€ Rae is already contending with superstardom and she illustrates how becoming more famous can feel unbridled and sometimes even violent. â€œFame is a gun and I point it blind / Crash and burn, girl, baby, swallow it dry / You got a front row seat and I / I got a taste of the glamorous life.â€ As a pop star, Rae comes from a unique position. While some of her contemporaries, like Olivia Rodrigo, also found fame before they made the transition to music, Rae didnâ€™t come from television or another platform where she may have found mentors to guide her. Her fame came from filming in her living room, and sheâ€™s had to learn how to navigate the public eye mostly on her own. â€œMy life moves faster than me,â€ she sings in â€œTimes Like These.â€ â€œCanâ€™t feel the ground beneath my feet.â€ All throughout the record, Rae wants to enjoy her success, but a fear lingers in the background of what accomplishing her dreams could ultimately do to her life.', 'It was evident that Rae is a student of pop when she arrived to the 2024 VMAs in a bridal-inspired, underwear-baring ensemble from Miss Claire Sullivan that paid homage to her pop foremothers, Britney Spears and Madonna. On Addison, the singer hopes to join the ranks of all the greats who came before her, and her references are varied and fascinating. â€œMoney Is Everythingâ€ directly calls these stars out by name. â€œAnd when Iâ€™m up dancing, please, DJ, play Madonna / Wanna roll one with Lana, get high with Gaga,â€ Rae proclaims. But she also makes references to more niche stars. In â€œMoney,â€ Rae also has Natasha Bedingfield on her mind, with a reference to her â€œpocketful of sunshine.â€ Meanwhile, tracks like â€œIn the Rainâ€ and â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ sound as if they couldâ€™ve been recorded by early aughts stars like Hilary Duff or Ashlee Simpson. The juttering intro on â€œHigh Fashionâ€ couldâ€™ve come straight from an FKA Twigs album, while â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ is heavily Lana Del Rey-coded. Like ghosts guiding her forward, the presence of pop ancestors can be felt everywhere throughout the record.', 'Although she makes her many nods to pop divas, itâ€™s clear that Rae has found something truly unique on Addison. Put on â€œSummer Foreverâ€ or â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and youâ€™ll find a sonic universe that makes you feel like youâ€™re floating. Youâ€™ll find yourself hitting play over and over. Dreamy synths mingle with twinkly piano keys and stuttering beats glitch and fuzz before dissipating into the air. Addison may look to her pop forebears for inspiration, but she isnâ€™t too concerned with following trends. Recently, some stars have been going down the country lane, while others are leaning into quiet indie pop. Here, the â€œAquamarineâ€ singer has formed a landscape all her own, and it will be interesting to see how she builds upon this with future music.', 'What makes Addison work is that you can tell our titular pop heroine is simply having fun. While sheâ€™s not afraid to touch on darker issues like family strife, body dysmorphia, and the pressures of fame, Addison keeps things relatively light. She just wants a cigarette and a good time. â€œYou know, I actually donâ€™t mind people experiencing me in a very honest and open way,â€ the singer told Zane Lowe in a recent Apple Music interview. â€œReally, any space as long as it is right here. I will allow anyone in my space.â€ Thatâ€™s precisely why her songs, and their accompanying visuals, have stood out. Whether sheâ€™s donning neon pink wigs, rolling around in powdered sugar, or letting her background dancers throw her around like a rag doll, Addison isnâ€™t afraid of being a little weird, and her work is all the better for it. To quote another pop star: Sheâ€™s just being Addison.', 'Every Photo From BeyoncÃ©â€™s Cowboy Carter Tour', 'Rico Nasty Has Always Been the Reference', 'Is Celibacy the Secret to a More Satisfying Life?', 'The L Word Changed Queer Television Forever', 'Bazaar Book Chat: "Set Piece" by Lana Schwartz', 'Nadia Lee Cohen on Her New Book, Julie Bullard', 'The Biggest Takeaways From â€œSomething Beautifulâ€', 'Every Ali Hazelwood Book, Ranked', 'Kali Uchis\'s "Most Vulnerable" Ever Album is Here', '36 Female Artists You Need to Know', 'â€œCareless Peopleâ€ Is the Final Girl-Boss Memoir', 'Jorja Smith Is Ready to Soundtrack Your Summer', 'A Part of Hearst Digital Media', 'We may earn commission from links on this page, but we only recommend products we back.', 'Â©2025 Hearst Magazine Media, Inc. Title: Addison Rae Builds an Irresistible Pop Fantasy in â€˜Addisonâ€™ â€” One Thatâ€™s Too Weird to Be Fake: Album Review
Paragraphs: ['', '', 'Reinvention is an unusual concept to apply to someone at the beginning of their career. Transformation usually follows a clear introduction â€” a breakout role, a first book, a memorable performance. But in the case of Addison Rae, the idea of a â€œrebrandâ€ defined her artistic breakthrough from the very beginning. Even as she earned credibility through co-signs and collaborations from shapeshifting tastemakers like Charli xcx and Arca, those endorsements only deepened the question: is this the product of a manufactured reinvention, or was this who she was all along?', 'To fully grasp the ethos of â€œAddison,â€ the 24-year-old TikTok sensation turned pop singerâ€™s major label debut, youâ€™d have to revisit the peaks and pitfalls of Addison Rae. As she became more of an influential figure on the viral dance and lip-syncing app, Rae worked to expand her presence in acting, music and business, even launching her own beauty line and starring in the Netflix film â€œHeâ€™s All That.â€ She released her debut single, â€œObsessed,â€ produced by Benny Blanco, in 2021, though it was commercially unsuccessful.', 'More from Variety', "Addison Rae on the All-Woman Team Behind Her Self-Titled Debut and Being Pop's Next 'It' Girl: 'This Is My Shot. I've Got to Go Big'", "Addison Rae Announces Release Date for Debut Album 'Addison'", "Addison Rae Releases 'Headphones On,' the Fourth Single Off Her Upcoming Debut Album", 'Things were quiet for a while until a batch of Raeâ€™s old demos began to gain traction online, with a niche group of alternative pop fans demanding an official release. Simply labeled â€œAR,â€ the four-song set arrived in 2023, and included what is now widely regarded as a standout single, â€œ2 Die 4.â€ While some celebrated the simplicity of the song and its catchy verses â€” â€œMy neck, 2 die 4 / My legs, 2 die 4 / This ah-ah sex, 2 die 4â€³ â€” others jumped to criticize her for it.', 'Over the last seven months, the singles for â€œAddisonâ€ arrived like clues, each more alluring than the last, filled with lush, sophisticated arrangements of glimmering, fuzzy pop melodies. â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ and then â€œAquamarine,â€ â€œHigh Fashion,â€ â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and â€œFame Is a Gunâ€ all surpassed her previous work.', 'Rae flaunts an unadulterated freedom in her music that could easily be construed as juvenile or, well, weird. We got a clear taste of that in her feature on Charliâ€™s â€œVon Dutch (Remix),â€ where at one point, she lets out a high-pitched scream that simmers. Though you could classify it as an unsettling disruption, the ad-lib became a trademark of the song. The same could be said here of the intro and outro of the trippy hip-hop breaks in â€œMoney Is Everything,â€ which start somewhere sexy and slightly disorienting, and end in a state of ebullient bliss and borderline delusion.', 'In all of the promotion leading up to this release, Rae has made it a point that she and her collaborators approached the recording process without any direct influences in mind. Despite this, itâ€™s hard not to draw comparisons to its most obvious touchstones, from Charliâ€™s â€œBratâ€-era tech house beats (see: â€œNew Yorkâ€) to Lana Del Reyâ€™s melancholic refrains (â€œSummer Foreverâ€) and the foundational aesthetics of Madonna and Britney Spears. But like most of her Gen-Z peers in pop, Rae is a student of the genreâ€™s best and brightest; she wields relics of nostalgic imagery (at this point in time, that looks like wired headphones and a third generation iPod Nano) where they matter most, making references to her idols in a narrative that is still largely her own creation.', 'There is also no denying the lift of co-producers Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd â€” Raeâ€™s only billed producers and co-writers on â€œAddison,â€ apart from Swedish songwriter Tove Burman, who has songwriting credits on â€œLost and Foundâ€ and â€œHigh Fashion.â€ Kloser and AnderfjÃ¤rd arenâ€™t afraid to play with sound in unique ways, chopping spacey and rhythmic elements to complement Raeâ€™s breathy vocals, like a carefully constructed puzzle.', 'After listening to the songs on â€œAddisonâ€ in their intended order, what becomes equally as intriguing are the lyrical themes, fueled by emotion and articulated in digestible one-liners and definitive affirmations: â€œI know the lows are what make the highs higher,â€ she sings in â€œHeadphones On,â€ like something youâ€™d underline in a wellness planner; â€œLifeâ€™s no fun through clear waters.â€ She finds comfort in her own systems of escapism, oftentimes leaving empowered by the moments she feels misunderstood or vulnerable.', 'Will this be enough to catapult Rae to the upper echelons of pop? Her determination alone demands consideration, even from those whose initial curiosities are fueled by skepticism. Either way, sheâ€™s managed to open the conversation â€” and that might be the most radical move of all.', 'Best of Variety', '25 Hollywood Legends Who Deserve an Honorary Oscar', 'New Movies Out Now in Theaters: What to See This Week ', "Emmy Predictions: Animated Program â€” Can Netflix Score Big With 'Arcane,' 'Devil May Cry' and the Final Season of 'Big Mouth?'", "Sign up for Variety's Newsletter. Paragraphs: ['In just one year, Addison Rae has invented herself. Once a ditzy TikTok star dancing for Jimmy Fallon and shaking hands with President Trump, sheâ€™s joined the it-girl posse of Charli xcx and Lorde, and gained new influences in Lana Del Rey, Madonna, and BjÃ¶rk. Her star-making string of single releases (along with their often artsy and self-serious videos) reintroduced her as an astute chronicler of pop, a fun girl who wears her influences on her sleeve and can make a damn good song while sheâ€™s at it. If you pretend to be esoteric long enough, that might just be who you are.', 'â€˜Addisonâ€™, her long-awaited debut album, is helmed by Rae and her two producers Luka Kloser and ELVIRA, a crafty duo that create a rich roadmap of Raeâ€™s many influences, which arenâ€™t always in the same decade. â€˜Addisonâ€™ feels uniquely fresh, even when tapping into trip-hop on â€˜Headphones Onâ€™ or â€˜Ray Of Lightâ€™-era Madonna trance on â€˜Aquamarineâ€™. And when theyâ€™re not imitating, they can put forth a pop song as sleek as ever, replete with small, clever moments like a Radiohead-like melody that starts â€˜Times Like Theseâ€™ or the stutter-stepping synths into the final chorus of â€˜High Fashionâ€™, which already sounds like one of the alien, icy beats FKA twigs or BANKS helmed in the mid-2010s.', 'Itâ€™s worth mentioning that â€˜Addisonâ€™ shows all of its tricks too early â€” the pre-release singles stomp any and all album tracks, to the point where listening to the final record doesnâ€™t feel like discovering something new, rather seeing more pockets of her persona. Could you imagine if â€˜Headphones Onâ€™ was kept as a secret; the mesmerizing, string-based closer that reveals a depth to Rae in the recordâ€™s final moments? Fame is a gun, but itâ€™s also a marathon, not a sprint.', 'For the most part, â€˜Addisonâ€™ is a fun, delicious ride, soundtracking a movie where a small-town girl wins the lottery and parties it up in New York City. The sensual chorus on â€˜Diet Pepsiâ€™ will go down in history, as will the glowing, spoken-verse on â€˜Aquamarineâ€™: â€œHeart of the Ocean around my neck,â€ she gasps, drowning in luxury. The joy she feels on the trap-inflected â€˜Money is Everythingâ€™ is palpable: â€œIâ€™m the richest girl in the world!â€ she yells at the end, believable and bubbly. She dons a syrupy voice mixing early-aughts Kylie, Fergie and Britney on â€˜Fame is a Gunâ€™, singing â€œI got a taste of the glamorous lifeâ€; the repetition of â€œlove New York / feel so freeâ€ on the ode to the city has an earnest, â€˜aw, shucks!â€™ quality, like an excited puppy wagging its tail at any passerby. ', 'For all of the fun moments, â€˜Addisonâ€™ can get quite melancholy. â€˜Fame is a Gunâ€™ dresses it up in a fun metaphor, and â€˜In The Rainâ€™ is an often-used solution to disguising tears, but thereâ€™s no hiding her sadness in the trippy â€˜Times Like Theseâ€™, where Rae repeats her confusion and asks, â€œAm I too young to be this mad? Am I too old to blame my dad?â€ Itâ€™s an affecting number about quick-moving fame, but she ends its chorus obliquely singing, â€œIn times like these, itâ€™sâ€¦ itâ€™s how it has to be,â€ which is like ending a strong speech and flubbing the final line. However, its detachment and acceptance fit well with her surrender (â€œItâ€™s not my fate in the endâ€), which she echoes on â€˜Headphones Onâ€™. ', 'At a brisk thirty minutes and a far-from-seamless build, â€˜Addisonâ€™ reflects more what Rae enjoys rather than who she is. But who can blame a girl who, at her first opportunity, throws all of her influences in a blender to make a tapestry of what she grew up on? â€˜Addisonâ€™ is a masterful pop album that comes from the heart, and thereâ€™s not many of those around right now.', '8/10', 'Words: Sam Franzini', 'â€”', 'â€”', '', 'Join us on WeAre8, as we get under the skin of global cultural happenings. Follow Clash Magazine HERE as we skip merrily between clubs, concerts, interviews and photo shoots. Get backstage sneak-peeks and a view into our world as the fun and games unfold.', ' ']

Title: Addison Raeâ€™s debut album proves her evolution from influencer to pop heavyweight is complete
Paragraphs: ['', '', 'On her carefree debut, the US musician has gone mononymous and enlisted Swedish producers to help craft a Nineties and Y2K scrapbook that balances pop, past and present but never feels too try-hard', "From reproductive rights to climate change to Big Tech, The Independent is on the ground when the story is developing. Whether it's investigating the financials of Elon Musk's pro-Trump PAC or producing our latest documentary, 'The A Word', which shines a light on the American women fighting for reproductive rights, we know how important it is to parse out the facts from the messaging.", '', '', 'In a recent New York Times interview, the American musician Addison Rae said she realised â€œhow much choice and taste is kind of a luxuryâ€. Itâ€™s a telling comment from someone who has built her debut album around carefully curated sonic references, but achieved fame by dancing to viral sounds on social media. You get the sense sheâ€™s finally getting to make her mark, the way she wants to. From 90s-era Madonna to the melancholy shades of Lana del Rey, Rae proves herself a devoted student of pop, while managing to shape an intimate, personal sound with its own hallmarks.', 'There will probably always be a degree of lingering snobbery around Rae. Having launched her career as a social media personality whoâ€™d dance to tracks that labels paid her $20 to promote, the Louisiana-born singer quickly became one of the platformâ€™s biggest faces. Her 2023 debut EP, AR, made a stir in internet circles, but its ultra-slick, high-gloss brand of pop never quite converted the sceptics. For many, the leap from influencer to credible musician felt like a stretch.', 'Addison goes a long way toward changing that. The full-length is a nod to pop past and present, honouring these influences while not leaning too heavily on them. Even its high-saturation artwork is a homage to Y2K It girls including Hilary Duff and Christina Aguilera, with a pinch of grainy Tumblr aesthetics. When making her case for a record deal, Rae brought along a mood board with the words â€œintentionalâ€, â€œintenseâ€, â€œloudâ€, â€œdanceâ€ and â€œglitterâ€ along with colours â€“ aquamarine and hot pink. The theme of girlhood is ever-present on Addison, from referencing Sofia Coppola in her videos to lines like â€œStayinâ€™ up all night long / Singinâ€™ our favourite songsâ€ nodding to simple times of youth on â€œSummer Foreverâ€.', 'When she announced the record on Instagram, Rae wrote that the music came from â€œa deep desperation and desire to understand myself betterâ€. As well as moments of carefree popstar decadence, thereâ€™s introspection. â€œHeadphones Onâ€ explores her parentsâ€™ divorce (â€œWish my mom and dad couldâ€™ve been in love / Guess some things arenâ€™t meant to last foreverâ€) while â€œFame is a Gunâ€ addresses the rollercoaster of celebrity and the weight of expectation (â€œCrash and burn, girl, baby, swallow it dryâ€). The lyric â€œI got a taste of the glamorous lifeâ€, meanwhile, is a nod to Sheila Eâ€™s 1984 track â€œThe Glamorous Lifeâ€ â€“ and perhaps also a dash of Fergie.', 'Throughout, Rae wears her references proudly on her sleeve. Her mentor Charli xcx has a clear influence on opener â€œNew Yorkâ€, with its â€œbig appleâ€ lyrics and glimmers of hyperpop. Raeâ€™s breathy coo that opens â€œMoney Is Everythingâ€ is pure Britney, even down to her studied pronunciation of the word â€œmoneyâ€, and Rae is an admitted Spears superfan (see: the staged paparazzi shots of her reading Britneyâ€™s memoir in 2023). â€œSummer Foreverâ€ has glistening strokes of Enyaâ€™s new age synths, while the trip-hop track â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ recalls Madonnaâ€™s Ray Of Light.', 'The entire album is the product of Rae working exclusively with an all-female production crew: Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd and Luka Kloser, who are signed to Max Martinâ€™s publishing company. From the swinging synths on â€œHigh Fashionâ€ to the nu-disco pulse of â€œNew Yorkâ€, the production blends commercial pop tropes with some of the weirdness that has historically been key in making chart cuts stand the test of time. At times, you wish theyâ€™d push that weirdness further â€“ Raeâ€™s sweeping, dreamy sonics are cohesive, but the album could benefit from more moments of contrast.', 'Alongside Addisonâ€™s rollout, Rae has demonstrated a consistent ability to position herself as an attention-grabbing artist, whether through spinning through clouds of white powder in the video to â€œHigh Fashionâ€ or posing in front of a sign for the uninspiring supermarket chain Iceland to promote â€œHeadphones Onâ€. All this goes to show, as Charli xcxâ€™s Brat did recently, that marketing and the culture surrounding a record can be as crucial as the music itself.', 'Addison Rae may have started out as an internet personality, but Addison earns her a seat at the pop table. Rather than a work of fluke or novelty, it marks the arrival of an artist who knows exactly what sheâ€™s doing.', 'Join thought-provoking conversations, follow other Independent readers and see their replies', '']

Even before her debut album Addison dropped today, the 24-year-old had already managed to become the sixth-most followed account on TikTok, star in Netflix original series Heâ€™s All That, create a hit podcast, model for Saint Laurent and Praying, feature in perhaps the most iconic remix album of all time, and even secure the top spot on Dazedâ€™s best tracks of 2024.', 'What is certain about Addison Rae, however, is that she is now cemented as one of the worldâ€™s most exciting new pop stars. In less than a year since the synth-pop, bad b summer anthem â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ appeared on charts globally, Rae has attracted comparisons to Britney Spears and the dreamy alt-pop stylings of Lana Del Rey, while the latest project takes cues from 1998 album Ray of Light by the Queen of Pop herself: Madonna. Itâ€™s a pop girl pastiche that Rae herself acknowledges on the albumâ€™s fourth track â€œMoney is Everythingâ€, singing: â€œDJ play Madonna, Wanna roll one with Lana, Get high with Gaga.â€', 'Speaking in advance of Addisonâ€™s release, album collaborators Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd explained that the â€œsonic lynchpinâ€ of the project is the Korg M1 synthesiser, which was a staple of Madonnaâ€™s house-pop crossovers in the 90s. On tracks like â€œLost & Foundâ€ and â€œIn the Rainâ€, this artistic direction adds a much-needed bite to Raeâ€™s otherwise straightforward youthful hedonism, blending in with Raeâ€™s layered, reverb-drenched vocals to create the dream-pop soundscape that forms Addisonâ€™s central appeal. ', 'But the new project isnâ€™t just sunshine and beaches. As Addison reaches penultimate interlude track â€œLifeâ€™s No Fun Through Clear Watersâ€, the viral star has gone from partying through the â€œSummer Foreverâ€ to crying â€œIn The Rainâ€ and lamenting â€œTimes Like Theseâ€. But, with lyrics like â€œWhen it comes to shoes Iâ€™ll be your slutâ€ and â€œIâ€™m gonna go down in history, donâ€™t ask too many questionsâ€, itâ€™s delivered with a disarming transparency that makes Rae somewhat of a relatable superstar. While not reinventing the wheel, Addison certainly cements Raeâ€™s position as the 21st centuryâ€™s brightest new pop star.', 'Below, to celebrate the release of Addison Raeâ€™s Addison, the Dazed team selects their top ten tracks from the album (number one being the very best). ', 'I like this song, but Iâ€™m just too broke and embittered to truly enjoy listening to a millionaire sing about being rich, even if theyâ€™re doing so ironically or in the service of some vague social critique â€“ itâ€™s a bop though! (JG)', 'I find it hard to write about Addison Raeâ€™s music without googling synonyms for â€œsultryâ€ â€“ but what else can I say? Sheâ€™s a sultry artist, and â€œHigh Fashionâ€ is a sultry song, or perhaps a voluptuous, sensual, alluring and luscious one. The production is pleasantly languid and the lyrics, while a little obvious in parts ( â€œmaking out in the car, doing shots at the barâ€, etc) capture the sense of expansive possibility which the best summers have â€“ anything could happen baby! This is a solid album track, but after a few listens, it hasnâ€™t blown me away like some of the others. (JG)', '', 'This song, to me, is a â€˜maladaptive daydreaming on a long walkâ€™ anthem. Honestly, sheâ€™s right, put your headphones on, listen to a good song, and just get over it. That chorus (guess I got to accept the pain, need a cigarette to make me feel better / every good thing comes my way) is a bit earnest, a bit 00s, a bit cheesy pop â€“ but it works! Let it be and let go! (HD)', 'With each new single that she dropped in the run-up to her album release, a new pop banger was born. Somehow, Addison Rae managed to score a perfect five out of five for her single rollout and â€œFame Is A Gunâ€ was no exception. Rumour has it, the lyrics are a reference to Sheila Eâ€™s 1984 track â€œThe Glamorous Lifeâ€, which was written by Prince (and what better way to secure banger status than with a little Prince magic?). (IVD)', 'This is crawling up the ranking every time I play it. Although itâ€™s one of the most sonically original songs on the album â€“ those propulsive, shimmering synths, combined with Raeâ€™s breathy vocals, feel almost euphorically extraterrestrial â€“ it still features some knowing winks to her pop icon foremothers (â€œI strike a poseâ€, â€œIf youâ€™re offended, say a prayerâ€). Say what you want about Raeâ€™s love of pastiche, but she at least has immaculate taste. â€œIn The Rainâ€ sweeps you away, like all the best pop songs should. (DS)', 'This is one of our favourites of the previously unreleased material â€“ itâ€™s so dreamy and sultry and gently euphoric. This is probably the song which sounds most inspired by 90s Madonna, along with a touch of All Saints and that kind of Balearic The Beach soundtrack atmosphere. But while it wears its influences on its sleeve, itâ€™s not overpowered by them â€“ sheâ€™s forging a distinctive sound, and it still sounds like an Addison Rae song. (JG)', 'â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ came out right after my ex and I broke up, and without exaggeration, I listened to it on repeat for three days straight, dreaming about a deranged rebound and re-losing my own innocence in the back seat. â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ is pop music at its best: giddy, effervescent and exhilarating (the key change at the end is hands down one of this yearâ€™s most euphoric musical moments.) (JG)', 'Following the previously released singles, I had high expectations pressing play on this album. But honestly, I was not expecting to open with a song like â€œNew Yorkâ€. Donâ€™t cancel me, but having a real love for NYC can actually feel like a religious experience, and this song encapsulates that feeling of arriving in the best city on earth, full of life and hope. Granted, most people are likely not arriving at the Bowery Hotel, but she still makes good points. Also, that pounding drumbeatâ€¦ sensational. 10/10, no notes. (HD)', 'While I loved â€œDiet Pepsiâ€,  it wasnâ€™t until the release of â€œAquamarineâ€ that I became properly excited about Addisonâ€™s new direction, that I thought â€œthis chica has got the juiceâ€¦â€. While obviously inspired by Ray of Light and 90s eurodance, it doesnâ€™t just feel like an exercise in nostalgia â€“ the production is fresh and interesting, the melody is gorgeous, and Addisonâ€™s vocals are as exactly as restrained as they need to be (â€œsultryâ€, you might even say!) â€œAquamarineâ€ is a classic in the making, and the song which cemented her status as a major new pop talent. (JG)']

Title: Addison Raeâ€™s â€˜Addisonâ€™ Album: All 12 Tracks Ranked
Paragraphs: ['With her anticipated self-titled debut album, Addison Rae solidifies her pop star status.', 'Addison Raeâ€™s rise to main pop girl is equal parts master class and modern spectacle. Having started on TikTok, becoming one of the platformâ€™s top users known for choreographing brief dances to catchy hits, Rae always had her sights set on a bigger stage â€” literally.', 'In the past year, sheâ€™s performed onstage with Charli xcx and Troye Sivan at the New York stop of their Sweat Tour, and at Coachella this past April, Rae performed again with Charli but also Arca, who remixed Raeâ€™s â€œAquamarineâ€ into a track titled â€œArcamarineâ€ months prior. During the live performance, Rae unveiled her debut albumâ€™s release date, writing â€œJune 6â€ on her underwear.', 'Now â€“ nearly one year after the release of her hit single â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ â€” June 6 has come and the moment is Raeâ€™s alone to bask in. Across her debut albumâ€™s 12 tracks, there are two interludes and zero features; all songs were co-written by Rae, alongside collaborators Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd.', 'And while for many this moment has felt like a long time coming for the fast-rising, always captivating pop artist, it may just as soon come to an end; as Raeâ€™s website states under each available item (including a CD, black, light blue and tangerine vinyl and a sold-out box set) Addison is â€œthe first and last album by Addison Rae.â€', 'If the album is a one-and-done, itâ€™s immediately iconic. An accomplishment surrounded by whispers of â€œshe did that.â€ Or, it could be nothing more than an indication that the Addison Rae the Internet has come to know is simply shifting before our eyes. Rae even said in her ELLE cover story that sheâ€™s going by â€œjust Addison now.â€', 'Whatever comes next for the artist, she can always look back on Addison as a project that is entirely her â€” and perhaps far more honest and vulnerable than even she anticipated to be. As a result, Raeâ€™s debut proves her to be one of one among popâ€™s current crew. So whether or not thereâ€™s more to come, just put your â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and hit repeat â€“ and read below for Billboardâ€™s ranking of all 12 tracks.', 'The opening notes on Addisonâ€™s first interlude are distinctly similar to those of â€œAquamarine,â€ the track directly before it, only the sun-kissed, effervescent energy of the latter is replaced by moody, languid synths. Raeâ€™s repeated sentiment of â€œI lost myself and found myself againâ€ echoes off the walls of the production, soon giving way to her booming, layered chanting. The interlude proves that the pop star is unafraid to get introspective â€” even if only for a brief moment.', 'â€œLifeâ€™s no fun through clear waters,â€ a siren-like voice echoes and repeats over a string section, (plucking a lyric straight from â€œHeadphones Onâ€). Though it arrives as the second-to-last track on the album, it serves as a reminder of the projectâ€™s entire motto: this should be fun. Isnâ€™t that the point? Addison acts as one big reminder that the plot isnâ€™t perfection â€” because how boring would that be?', 'It feels like a given to include a track called â€œSummer Foreverâ€ on an album arriving at the top of June, just weeks before the official first day of the season. Raeâ€™s breezy vocals and the songâ€™s minimal yet immersive production are perfect companions for sheer drapes billowing in the wind on a balcony door left open â€” a clear indicator of a summer day well spent. (Plus, if pitched down, this could just as easily be a song by Lana Del Rey, queen of summertime sadness.)', 'â€œHave you ever dreamt of being seen?/ Not by someone, more like in a magazine,â€ Rae asks to open the albumâ€™s third single, â€œHigh Fashion.â€ Sheâ€™s seemingly intent on doing whatever it takes to pull off a look worthy enough, rejecting passing thrills â€” drugs and cheap love â€” in its pursuit. Itâ€™s not her most complicated song on the album, but who says a pop hit canâ€™t hang its hat on thumping bass and a deep love for couture? Not Addison Rae, thatâ€™s for damn sure.', 'One of the more subdued, airy songs on the album (alongside â€œSummer Foreverâ€ and â€œTimes Like Theseâ€), â€œIn the Rainâ€ offers a glimpse into the Addison behind the layers of tulle on her album cover. â€œYoung dumb and cute nothing to lose/ And now the past is someone that I have to answer for/I got a whole new point of view,â€ she sings at the top of the track, before concluding: â€œMisunderstood but Iâ€™m not gonna sweat it.â€ While the writing stands out as some of Raeâ€™s most vulnerable, the song is tucked in between similar-sounding â€œSummer Foreverâ€ and the higher-energy â€œFame Is A Gunâ€ â€” a smart move for a song about being inconspicuous.', 'â€œTimes Like Theseâ€ is like the angrier, somehow more honest sister to â€œIn the Rainâ€ â€” not evidenced at all by how it sounds, but solely by what Rae says. Itâ€™s almost as if crying in the rain (see: â€œIn the Rainâ€) didnâ€™t solve anything (shocking) and a few songs later Rae couldnâ€™t help but revisit the same wounds. â€œAm I too young to be this mad/ Am I too old to blame my dad,â€ she wonders aloud. Consider this song a warning, as itâ€™s Raeâ€™s most tender tracks that hit hardest.', 'Perhaps more so than anywhere else on Addison, â€œMoney Is Everythingâ€ calls back on what made 2023 EP AR such a cult classic among her core fan base: pure, unadulterated bubblegum-pop fun. Sheâ€™s drawing comparisons to Marilyn Monroe â€” referring to the late icon by her birth name, of course â€” requesting Madonna at the DJ booth and fantasizing about a perfect night out with the pop girlies, all on top of a bouncy beat thatâ€™s as sweet as candy. And of all the quotable one-liners from Rae on the album, of which they run aplenty, her outro shriek of â€œMoney loves me!â€ just may take the cake.', 'The hustle and bustle of New York City isnâ€™t for everyone, but those who get it, well, they just get it. On Addisonâ€™s opener, Rae adds to the canon of love letters to the Big Apple with a track primed for the dance floor. Sheâ€™s moving at a pace to make any tried-and-true New Yorker proud, hardly stopping to drop her bags off at the Bowery Hotel before heading straight to the club. Itâ€™s an apropos tone-setter for the rest of the album: Donâ€™t get too comfortable and donâ€™t get too complacent because much like the city itself, sheâ€™s always going to keep you on your toes.', 'When â€œAquamarineâ€ arrived, it felt almost obvious that this is what an Addison Rae album would sound like: glittering, confident and dance-floor ready. But now, when heard in the context of the album itself, a song like â€œAquamarineâ€ is actually an outlier. â€œIâ€™m not hiding, anymore,â€ sings Rae. â€œIâ€™m free.â€ And while itâ€™s not the only time Rae sings of feeling free on Addison, (she does so on â€œNew Yorkâ€ as well), it is far from the theme of the album; much of Addison is about a time when she felt quite the opposite, but made the best of it anyway on her road to liberation.', 'Itâ€™s deeply admirable how consistent Rae is about her proclivity toward fame throughout the entire album. â€œNothing makes me feel as good as being loved by you,â€ she sings in one of her most honest moments during a brief lull in the trackâ€™s pace. She lets the spotlight steer her (â€œTell me who I amâ€); implores it for its lustrous shine (â€œWhen you shame me, it makes me want it moreâ€); and eliminates any doubt about her right to exist within it (â€œThereâ€™s no mystery/Iâ€™m gonna make it, gonna go down in historyâ€). If all the worldâ€™s a stage, Rae is stopping nothing short of standing front and center.', 'Ending her debut album with the already-released and widely loved â€œHeadphones Onâ€ is pure brilliance. As the song and music video make clear, â€œHeadphones Onâ€ is an ode to music as an escape â€” arguably one of the most relatable sentiments of all. Closing Addison â€” an album that is so subtly steeped in various traumas â€” with a song about accepting the pain proves that Rae is not only an artist with a vision, but an artist who is more self aware than she gets credit for. â€œHeadphones Onâ€ even has self-referential lines like â€œlifeâ€™s no fun through clear waters,â€ a sentence that gets its own interlude, or â€œsoaking up the rain,â€ a nod to â€œIn the Rainâ€ â€” and it all points to the same thing. Addison Rae knows exactly what sheâ€™s doing. Sheâ€™s been listening carefully, and now, itâ€™s the listenerâ€™s turn to do the same.', 'Nine months later and â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ is still just as refreshing as ever. From the very beginning, it has always felt like the kind of song that demonstrates how well Rae has her finger on the pulse of pop today. It showcases her ability to craft a punchy hook ready to wrap around your brain (and your heart) for days on end. It winks at the listener just enough to know Rae is in on the bit, but not so self-indulgent that it feels corny or warrants an eye roll. Title: Addison Rae Found Catharsis on the Dance Floor With Her Live Debut of â€˜Addisonâ€™
Paragraphs: ['On the eve of her albumâ€™s release, Spotify and Addison hosted an intimate performance for devotees at New Yorkâ€™s iconic nightclub, The Box.', 'Addison Rae lost herself and found herself again.', 'With the release of her highly anticipated debut album, we saw a rebirth right before our eyes. Rebirth, rebrand, reintroductionâ€”whatever you call itâ€”the Louisiana-born TikTok dancer transformed into one of the most promising pop acts of the current age with the release of â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ last summer. Let it be known that this was the moment she unlocked her potential as a Main Pop Girl in my eyes. From then on, I fully understood her vision.
