Title: Pop's brightest star Addison Rae drops dreamy debut album
Paragraphs: ['MUSIC NEWS FROM AROUND THE WORLD', 'Addison Rae has released her eagerly-anticipated debut album, Addison.', '', '', 'By Lizzie Baker', 'SHARE', 'Addison Rae has served up a dreamy pop album flaunting her â€œsensual and sexualâ€ personality.', 'The 24-year-old social media star has released her long-awaited self-titled debut studio effort - featuring the hit singles Diet Pepsi and Aquamarine.', '', 'She told Variety of the feelings she wanted to purvey: â€œWe definitely didnâ€™t reference anything making this album. It was always me trying to provoke a feeling from a song or from music. Iâ€™m a very sensual and sexual person. Iâ€™m very intimate with myself and my body, and everything kind of reflects that. Everything feels very personal.â€', 'Addison also shared that having her debut album - which, in true Addison style, she announced the release date for on her underwear at Coachella - produced entirely by women was â€œreally specialâ€.', 'The singer said working with Luka Kloser and Elvira on the record was â€œbeautiful and magicalâ€.', 'She explained: â€œI have something really special with these girls. It feels really beautiful and magical that it is just all females. I never set out for it to be that way, I think because itâ€™s not very common and you almost donâ€™t get that opportunity very much to work with just females in a room.â€', 'While she has been labelled the latest â€œIt girlâ€ in pop, Addison admitted she is wary of the praise.', 'She said: â€œIt is obviously very complimentary. What does that even mean, really, to be the pop girl? Letâ€™s see if the songs get more popular, then they can call me a pop girl. This is my shot. Iâ€™ve got to go big.â€', 'Meanwhile, Addison - who dropped her debut single Obsessed in 2023 - has spoken about how TikTok was the perfect launchpad for her career.', 'She told Zane Lowe on Apple Music 1: "I think in the beginning, especially, and starting out, I always knew that I wanted to make music. I always knew I wanted to act. I think I just knew I wanted to perform. That was just something that was really obvious to me since I was a little girl.', '"When TikTok happened, I was almost like, well, this seems like a really nice way to get myself to Los Angeles first, because I think in Louisiana there wasn\'t as many opportunities or like possibility, really, to pursue that profession necessarily, unless you just got really, really lucky."', "Addison gained popularity with her dance videos on TikTok in 2019, and by March 2020, rapper The Kid Laroi caused a buzz when he released a song titled Addison Rae, before she made her film debut in 2021's He's All That and released 'Obsessed' two years later."]

Title: Addison is an intriguing yet effective comeback from Addison Rae
Paragraphs: ['We may have witnessed one of this decadeâ€™s most satisfying rebrands yet.', 'â€œObsessedâ€ is merely a distant memory. The current Addison loves it still, but said sheâ€™s found her integrative musical ground, that is, the 90s and 00s dance-pop scenes. Youâ€™ll hear Mandy Mooreâ€™s self-titled on â€œTimes Like Theseâ€; Britney Spearsâ€™s Blackout on â€œFame Is a Gunâ€; Madonnaâ€™s Bedtime Stories on â€œHeadphones Onâ€ or Ray of Light on â€œAquamarineâ€ and â€œTimes Like Theseâ€. It fits her spectacularly well, hence a flop-exempt return. FKA twigsâ€™s EUSEXUA might be this recordâ€™s big sister for how similar their reference points are, yet thereâ€™s virtue in each and oneâ€™s own concoction of them. Unlike twigsâ€™s work, Addison wallows in the art of pastiche â€“ recalling Todd Haynesâ€™s referential queer films Ã  la Far From Heaven and Carol, whose everything apart from the screenplay mimics Douglas Sirkâ€™s melodrama â€“ and minds about originality at stripped minimum.', 'While Haynes meticulously conjures the eraâ€™s angelic, sublime atmosphere to underline and critique the historical erasure of gay and lesbian romance during the Lavender Hazeâ€™s high tides, Rae and her creative team do so for the â€œvibesâ€. ELVIRA and Luka Kloser, to their credit, did a nearly flawless job at imitating the canonsâ€™ stylistic intimacies. â€œIn the Rainâ€ features the snappy synths and sophisticated drums of Madonnaâ€™s â€œFrozenâ€ that tie well with Raeâ€™s sexy under-breath voice. â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ cherishes a scrumptious key change hardly present in todayâ€™s mainstream music, casting shafts of nostalgic light that turn Lana Del Reyâ€™s early risquÃ© allure into a lost 00s pop hit. Indeed, everything here sounds wonderful and emits an out-of-time quality so few have succeeded in attaining. But what else?', 'Of course, itâ€™s enough to excel in recalibrating tunes from a bygone era. Addisonâ€™s imperfections, however, are too blunt to be ignorable. â€œLifeâ€™s No Fun Through Clear Watersâ€ takes one great line from the closing track and abuses it in a tiresome refrain that ends too abruptly to stir up any visible emotion; even the BjÃ¶rkesque symphony, making such a forceful entrance at first, shrivels upon Raeâ€™s confused tracklisting. Another interlude â€œLost & Foundâ€ crushes the tantalizing momentum set by â€œAquamarineâ€, which, literally, is also about self-reinvention. It wouldâ€™ve worked if both had been given breadth and width to grow into fully fledged songs, exploring novel ideas that would contextualize the proceeding songsâ€™ moodier headspaces. They appear now more as fillers than substantial contributions to the albumâ€™s already lacklustre narrative.', 'Why does â€œHigh Fashionâ€â€™s bassline sound so intoxicating and disjointed? Why does â€œHeadphones Onâ€ possess trip-hop stems that are strangely symbolic of the destructive gallows? These interludes, if executed better, mightâ€™ve fulfilled and encouraged the listenersâ€™ curiosity such as mine over Raeâ€™s intriguing soundscapes. In simple words: there should be more than plain â€œvibesâ€ to evade shallowness and heighten singularity. Rae, ELVIRA and Kloser have undeniably great taste in canonical pop music, so how should its multi-facets present Raeâ€™s life as an influencer born in the age of TikTok? She has admitted that itâ€™s self-titled to embody her true self. Yet in the recent Apple Music podcast, Rae has proved to have ruminations and thoughtful comments on various subjects that exceed beyond just sexiness, lust and mundane heartbreaks. Where are those on here?', 'Take Addisonâ€™s closest references: Madonnaâ€™s Ray of Light and Britney Spearsâ€™s Breakout. They, too, have songs about love, fame and sex â€“ although with the off-center additions of Himalayan yoga classes (â€œShanti/Ashtangiâ€) that enraptured Madonna so much she once did it in a plane aisle, or peep shows (â€œFreakshowâ€) that gave Spears one of her careerâ€™s most riveting performances and showcased her heartshaped views on fractured everyday life. Addison has little of such specificity and eccentricity, opting instead for overused catch phrases like â€œsummer foreverâ€ and â€œI love New Yorkâ€. Her lyricism claws at a directness that borders on forgettability, if not except for some outliers as on Addison highlight â€œHigh Fashionâ€, where its opening verse lays bare her crude yearning for societal acceptance via fame, possibly winking at a deeper, more deprecating dissatisfaction with oneself.', 'Rae has much to improve upon, which isnâ€™t necessarily an unfavourable predicament. She still hasnâ€™t performed any song on her own; as of now, we have insufficent evidence to gauge her stage presence that will testify her capabilities as a well-equipped pop star with a formidable voice. She has few novelties to offer lyrically and sonically in this decadeâ€™s musical landscape. But one thing that deserves outright acclaim is her creative teamâ€™s idiosyncratic visual representations of the record. How long has it been since we got a series of music videos this good, this campy, this slay-the-house-down-boots? Albeit directed by a man, â€œAquamarineâ€â€™s video art is surreptitiously feminine and queer in its abrupt cutting and garish colors, a perfect fit for the song itself. Could this, then, be how she wants to be remembered â€“ as a singles and visual star who knows how to make a comeback, exhort hype, deliver a memorable era, and not much else?', 'Get the Best Fit take on the week in music direct to your inbox every Friday']

Title: 5 Best Moments From Addison Raeâ€™s Live Debut Performance of New Albumâ€™s Songs

With each release, she continues to carve out her own space in pop, and itâ€™s clear sheâ€™s well on her way to stardom.', 'The rising star performed seven songs from Addison for the first time at the intimate NYC venue: â€œFame Is a Gun,â€ â€œHigh Fashion,â€ â€œAquamarine,â€ â€œNew York,â€ â€œHeadphones Onâ€ â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ and â€œTimes Like These.â€ Here are the five best moments from her performance:', 'Addison Rae started off the night with her live performance of â€œFame Is a Gunâ€ as the curtains of The Box opened to reveal her in a vertical silk bed that her dancers pushed her out on stage with. Her dancers then ripped off the silk sheets to reveal Rae restrained by her arms and her legs while wearing burlesque-style lingerie.', 'â€œI have a question for you,â€ she told the crowd. â€œHave you ever dreamt of being seen?â€ she sang as she segued into her second song of the night with an old Hollywood burlesque version of her recent single â€œHigh Fashion.â€ This sultry performance, with Rae wearing lingerie and heels, took fans back to the 1940s â€” think sparkles, glitter, heels and dancing while singing into a retro-style mic.', 'Addison made a quick change into a blue dress that complemented the songâ€™s mood, while her best friend Lexi read sultry, dark poetry as multiple mirrors were set up to surround the stage. Title: Addison Rae: Addison review â€“ 2025â€™s most refreshing star revels in popâ€™s shallow pleasures
Paragraphs: ['(Columbia)\nThe one-time TikTok dancerâ€™s remarkably cohesive debut spans Jersey club to R&B, and defies an obsession with â€˜loreâ€™ to suggest that the best pop isnâ€™t that deep', 'W\nhen Madonna came to the height of her powers in the late 90s and early 00s, it felt as though she had perfected a new mode of pop stardom, making icy, complex and uncannily incisive records such as Ray of Light and Confessions on a Dance Floor. Those albums are powered by a gripping interplay between detachment and intensity; they sound, to me, like attempts to make pop albums without any sense of ego. As if sheâ€™s saying: this isnâ€™t a Madonna record, itâ€™s a pop record.', 'Addison Raeâ€™s exceptional debut album reminds me of that unimpeachable run of Madonna records, understanding that supreme confidence and exceptional taste can sell even the most unusual album. Itâ€™s both familiar â€“ Rae is an artist who unapologetically lives and dies by her references â€“ and totally bold: I get the sense that she is less trying to say â€œthis is who I amâ€ as much as â€œthis is what pop should beâ€.', 'Raeâ€™s vision of pop is formally traditionalist â€“ she loves big choruses, euphoric key changes, huge builds â€“ but undeniably influenced by her past life as an inhabitant of content-creation HQ Hype House, after her dance videos made her one of the most-followed people on TikTok. The 24-year-old sees no cognitive dissonance in putting together seemingly mismatched aesthetic or emotional sensibilities, a quality that, to me, suggests supreme comfort with the practically dadaist experience of scrolling TikTokâ€™s For You page. Winsome opener New York explores frenetic Jersey club; on Headphones On, a warm-and-fuzzy 90s-style R&B track, she casually tosses off the lyric â€œwish my mom and dad couldâ€™ve been in loveâ€ as if it was an intrusive thought she just had to let out.', 'Although Addison covers a lot of ground musically, every song also sounds uncannily like it came out of the indie-electronica boom of the early 2010s; High Fashion, arguably the best song here, is a pitch-perfect throwback to early James Blake and second-album Mount Kimbie; Diet Pepsi is Lana Del Rey by way of Neon Indian. The recordâ€™s remarkable coherence can be chalked up to the fact that Rae worked with the same writer-producer duo, Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd and Luka Kloser, on every song â€“ a rare feat for a major-label pop debut, made rarer by the fact that big-budget pop records made exclusively by women are practically nonexistent. But a quick scan of AnderfjÃ¤rd and Kloserâ€™s credits suggests that Rae is in the driverâ€™s seat here; neither of them has ever made a song as laconically pretty as the EDM-scented Summer Forever, or as girlishly menacing as Fame Is a Gun.', 'If Addison has a mission statement, itâ€™s on the latter: â€œTell me who I am â€“ do I provoke you with my tone of innocence?â€ she asks at its outset. â€œDonâ€™t ask too many questions, that is my one suggestion.â€ Itâ€™s an invitation to take Raeâ€™s music at face value â€“ thereâ€™s no self-conscious dip into wilful silliness or laborious camp. Most of the time, Rae is stringing together vague abstractions in a way that shuns overinterpretation, like when she sings: â€œNo matter what I try to do / In times like these, itâ€™s how it has to beâ€, or returns to the phrase â€œLifeâ€™s no fun through clear watersâ€.', 'Addison arrives at a fortuitous time: Rae resists the 2020s impulse to intellectualise every pop album and is unencumbered by ham-fisted concepts, Easter eggs or ultra-prescriptive â€œloreâ€ that tells listeners what to think. Its casually incisive tone suggests Rae might be a great pop flÃ¢neuse in the vein of Madonna or Janet Jackson, drifting through the scene with alluring ease and a gimlet eye. But sheâ€™d probably tell me Iâ€™m overthinking it.', 'Thanks for reading 26 articles. Title: First there was darkness. Then there was Addison Rae
Paragraphs: ['', '', 'Leave a comment', 'Addison Raeâ€™s Addison: decadent, hazy, cosmopolitan cool.', 'Addison Rae, Addison', 'How did a TikTok personality end up with the yearâ€™s most anticipated pop album? The simple answer is because sheâ€™s Addison Rae and thatâ€™s what she does.', 'For years, Rae amassed TikTok followers (88 million of them) with her cute dance routines, delivered with a beaming smile and an All-American tan. Even if you werenâ€™t on TikTok, you mightâ€™ve recognised her from teaching Kourtney how to dance on Keeping Up with the Kardashians. Maybe you even heard The Kid Laroiâ€™s early tribute song in her honour.', 'The TikTok-to-talent pipeline has been fraught for many a social media star, but Rae cracked its code when she segued to music. In 2023, her EP AR bubbled to cult status after Charli XCX cosigned on the slinky 2 Die 4, and then Raeâ€™s piercing wail on Charli XCXâ€™s Von Dutch Remix became a defining sound of Brat Summer. Further cameos onstage alongside Charli XCX and Troye Sivan gave Rae clout and musicâ€™s snobbier set permission to pay attention.', 'Rae then went on a tear with a remarkable string of singles, all of which feature on her debut album Addison, including Diet Pepsi, where she eased into the gloomy romanticism of Lana Del Rey; Aquamarine, which evoked the deep house grooves of Ray of Light-era Madonna and Impossible Princess-era Kylie; and High Fashion, a perfectly demented pop song built on wompy synths, a drugged-out click, and Raeâ€™s lusty falsetto.', 'Better yet have been their matching music videos, where Rae â€“ in her element â€“ projects decadent glamour. She rolls around in couture; she chain-smokes cigarettes like a French person; she uses her body louchely when she dances, mostly in Louboutins, a wink to pop excess. (Proving the extent to which the taste-making establishment have sought her association, Raeâ€™s creative team now regularly includes indie director Sean Price Williams, choreographer Danielle Polanco, and Interview Magazineâ€™s Mel Ottenberg on creative design.)', 'By this point, the albumâ€™s already an afterthought. That it aims to be a statement, in the old school kinda way, is appreciated. Entirely overseen by Swedish producers Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd, the songs on Addison emit a hazy, twilight, cosmopolitan cool. They smell like petrichor and oud.', 'The album cuts not already released add to Raeâ€™s narrative. Opener New York is upbeat hyperpop charting Raeâ€™s arrival to big-city liberation, built around the evocative couplet â€œchew gum, kick drumâ€, a sort of Pink Pony Club for trashbags. The fabulously bratty Money is Everything finds Rae aligning herself with Marilyn Monroe over a bellowing trap beat and sing-songy kidsâ€™ chant, her mischievous energy turned infectious.', 'To obsessives, thereâ€™s been a playful sense of destiny in Raeâ€™s arrival to pop stardom: she was born and raised in Lafayette, Louisiana, barely two hours (and two decades) from Kentwood, the hometown of Britney Spears. Some foresee the second coming, but the goodwillâ€™s not been unanimous.', 'Look under any of her videos and youâ€™ll find a comment like â€œThis rebrand should be studied in schoolsâ€ â€“ the implication being that, while successful, Raeâ€™s evolution from online personality to pop artist has felt manufactured or inauthentic. (The idea that, god forbid, someone might develop better taste and influences later into their 20s and 30s, is inconceivable to this generation.)', 'Addicted to Addy: popâ€™s new superstar.', 'In interviews, Raeâ€™s palmed off her former girl-next-door persona on TikTok as marketing savvy. â€œTaste is a privilege,â€ she told the New York Times, suggesting sheâ€™d been actively maximising her algorithmic fame to better position herself to eventually manoeuvre beyond the app. But it lends a defensiveness to Addison that, if necessary on her debut, feels antithetical to Raeâ€™s personal world-building.', 'On Money is Everything, she screams her holy trinity as evidence of her pop bona fides: â€œDJ, play Madonna, wanna roll one with Lana, get high with Gaga, and the girl I used to be is still the girl inside of me!â€ . On In the Rain, over a sweet acid house beat that couldâ€™ve come from Saint Etienneâ€™s Foxbase Alpha, she laments that sheâ€™s â€œmisunderstood but Iâ€™m not gonna sweat it, isnâ€™t it all for the show?â€ On Diet Pepsi, Addisonâ€™s first single, she was seductively suggesting sheâ€™s â€œlosing all my innocenceâ€ at, câ€™mon, 24?', 'For some reason, it all reminds me of Camila Cabello, whose last album, C, XOXO, was its own attempt at a grungy reinvention. Pop fans rejected Cabelloâ€™s pivot, but thereâ€™s something in Addisonâ€™s nostalgic touchstones â€“ the Alanis yodels, the Janet adlibs, the â€™90s aesthetics â€“ that might be more palatable to most than Cabelloâ€™s adventurous tilt towards hyperpop and SoundCloud rap. Maybe what Iâ€™m saying is Camila Cabello walked so Addison Rae could run.', 'And run she has, all the way from TikTok to popâ€™s ruling class. And in Louboutins at that.', 'Addison by Addison Rae is out now.', 'Leave a comment', 'Copyright Â© 2025']

Title: Music Review: On Addison Raeâ€™s 'Addison,' a new pop powerhouse is born
Paragraphs: ['', 'WSOC Now', 'Latest Local News', 'Newscast covering important local topics and events', 'NEW YORK â€” (AP) â€” The pop album of the summer is here. Addison Rae\'s debut, "Addison," is full, stuffed with bejeweled, hypnotic pop songs for the post-"BRAT" crowd. Hedonism has a new hero.', 'For those who\'ve watched her rise, it\'s almost impossible to believe. It wasn\'t so long ago â€“ almost exactly a year into the COVID-19 pandemic â€“ that a young Rae went on "The Tonight Show" and taught its host Jimmy Fallon a few stiff, meme-able TikTok dance moves, then what made up the bulk of her career. It was met with almost immediate backlash, as is common for young women with viral posts. But she wielded it like a weapon: Social media celebrity begat acting roles for Rae, then a coveted collaboration with Charli XCX in the form of a "Von Dutch" remix, and now, at age 24, her final form: becoming the hyper-ambitious, hyper-femme pop star for the current moment.', 'As a full body of work, "Addison" taps into the genre-agnostic zeitgeist, where pop music appears edgy and elastic. The songs speak for themselves, from the pitch-shifted trip-hop "Headphones On" and the snapped percussion, minor chords, NSFW lyrics and vanishing synths of "High Fashion" to the Madonna"Ray of Light"-cosplay "Aquamarine" atop a house beat and its chantable, spoken chorus: "The world is my oyster / Baby, come touch the pearl / The world is my oyster / And I\'m the only girl."', '', '', '', '', '', 'Â© 2025 Cox Media Group. Title: In 2025, does an artistâ€™s roll-out matter more than their album?
Paragraphs:
['HOME / CULTURE / FEATURES', 'Enter the chronology of the hyper visual popstar.', 'Image credit: Columbia Records ', 'Today is the day. Not any day, for the record, but the day where Addison (sans Rae) has dropped her debut album Addison. Since the confirmation a couple weeks ago, a slew of things have happened all at once. She put out the now notorious â€˜Headphones onâ€™, which weâ€™ve elegised as our own millennial hangup. Our new pop princess has released a constellation of visuals, each more high-strung and elaborate than the last. ', "The Lana divergent-Americana route of â€˜Diet Pepsi' had the singer weaving in and out of a moving vehicle, title drink in hand. In â€˜Headphones onâ€™, sheâ€™s hopping over Icelandic boulders, fluoro-pink hair billowing behind her. Her fizzing falsetto sister, â€˜Fame is a Gunâ€™ followedâ€”the final piece of the puzzle before the entire album landed. In the music video, Addison is donning a different wigâ€”more of a peroxide blonde, paired with enormous tinted shadersâ€”from which she sulks behind at the crown of a dinner party. ", 'And thatâ€™s just on the matter of video work. Addison has scrapped the album cover twice, unseating the image of her younger self with a brand new visualâ€”a coral-hued design of the singer wrapped in a veil, her newly minted moniker printed on the side. Online, the anticipation has hummed until this very moment.  The roll-out has been extensive, to say the least. Yet even before the music had landed, many found one thing certainâ€”we are cresting the reign of a new pop princess. ', 'Image credit: Courtesy of Sabrina Carpenter ', 'Then in the case of Sabrina Carpenter, something else was decidedly afoot. The Sweetener songstress had uploaded a short teaser of herself sticking her hand out, in the hopes of nabbing anyoneâ€™s car on the highway. Sheâ€™s wearing pint-sized shorts and a white dress shirt tied at the rib, a cutaway, for those in the know, to Paul Verhoevenâ€™s Showgirls. â€˜This oneâ€™s about you!!â€ reads the instagram caption to the videoâ€”which many have taken to be an arrow to ex-partner Barry Keoghan. On Twitter, the video has racked up 553,000 likes. The preview is soundless, apart from a breathy â€œOh boy!â€ from Carpenter which punctuates the ending. The snippet also revealed that the tribute-in-song would drop at 8pm ET on June 5th. â€˜Manchildâ€™ will be the start of a new sonic slate from Carpenter, who has not dropped any music since the deluxe edition of Short nâ€™ Sweet in February. ', 'The hypervisualisation of the pop starâ€”or, should we say, marketing whiz?â€”has shifted the gameplay of music as an entirely commercial process. None of this is new. Music and marketing has generated a particularly robust arm of business in the entertainment sector for many years. But on the matter of how roll-outs weigh up compared to the actual music itself, the scales seem to be evening out. In order to be heard today, thereâ€™s an entire assembly line of marketing that has to travel before the music even gets pushed out. Which begs the question: do we care more about an album release than the album itself? ', 'Image credit: Columbia Records ', 'BeyoncÃ© can answer that. The Cowboy Carter tour is kicking off across the continent of Europe, with star-studded, horse-bucking sequencesâ€”Rumi and Blue Ivy amongst them. Knowles, who has created entire universes around her sequence of work, Acts I, II and III, has been evasive as to when (or even what) the final album will entail. Speculative trails over the thematics, release date and continuity of each act raged, but Knowles withheld. On the topic of the never-materialised visuals, Beyonce addressed the matter in her Renaissance concert film. â€œYou are the visual, baby,â€ the screen announces, before cutting to live footage of her 56-city tour. The film grossed $44.4 million worldwide. ', 'The conversation cannot continue in good faith without mention of Taylor Swift. Polarising as she may be, her recent re-acquiral of her entire musical catalogue has rocketed online. The image of a diminutive Swift with her records sprawled in a fan around her sealed the deal. Tearstreaked Swifties lauded the decision as meteoric in pop cultureâ€”which, in a way, it was. If an announcement of Swift retaining her body of workâ€”not even putting a single outâ€”reared this reaction, then music isnâ€™t really music without a marketing tail, is it? ', '', '', 'Image credit: Getty Images ', 'Onto Charli. Last year was, without reservation, the Brat year. The iconography of a lime green square spitting out title tracks in narrow Arial dominated everything in our field of vision. Her music project was ambitious, despite the metric of affected slovenliness she hauled. Von Dutch, 360s, baby tees, and a band of It girls, Charli XCX had the public eating right out her palm. And thanks to a well-placed capitalisation, sheâ€™s managed to further that influence through the revival of â€˜party 4 uâ€™ from her fourth studio album, â€˜How Iâ€™m feeling nowâ€™. A music video was released for the first time on May 15 this year, in alignment with the fifth anniversary of the original album release. New visuals, old song, and a brand new lease on lifeâ€”at least on TikTok. ', 'Image credit: Getty Images ', 'A sidebar: the formula is not for everyone. Least of all for Gangster Nancy Sinatra, Lana Del Rey, who, despite a pantheon of fans, (47.5 million on Spotify, did you know?) has never cohered to the structure of a roll-out. Her untitled album to follow â€˜Do you know thereâ€™s a tunnel under ocean boulevardâ€™ has been gathering dust for a while after two characteristic delays. Yet, the flame doesnâ€™t flicker. Her listenership has only shuttled upwards, especially after her historic performance at Coachella last year. The reason Del Rey lands out of hot water despite a tepid promotion of her singles at best, is because she is a shoo-in at what she does. The air of mystery anchors suspense, too, and lends itself to the singerâ€™s own notoriety. When Del Rey introduces a new body of work, itâ€™s at her live concerts. At her last Sydney concert in 2018, the singer dove into a then-unheard â€˜Happiness is a Butterflyâ€™ with very little preamble. She dangles the catnip before droves of her fans, who, despite not having much to work with release-wise, are connecting with Lanaâ€™s music, perhaps the way she wants her fanbase toâ€”in communion with herself, and with no flash. ', 'Image credit: Columbia Records ', 'Let us be very clear: cheap tricks do not make a good album. No matter how the machinery of marketing roll-outs churns away, the music still has to tick all the boxes. And in Addison Raeâ€™s case, just like her mentioned predecessors, sheâ€™s managed to have her cake and eat it too. â€˜Addisonâ€™, upon review, is a twelve track heavy-hitter that lives up to its premature fame. Entries like the spitting, XCX-modeled â€˜New Yorkâ€™, and the percussive soliloquy to the lovelorn ways of â€˜Summer Foreverâ€™ all synthesise a body of work that, despite its briefness, is solid. Rae is an artist who has honed in on how to sell her sonic identity while still figuring it out. From her earliest days contorting in front of her phone, maybe one of the reasons sheâ€™s succeeding is because Addisonâ€™s always been in charge of her own visuals. Title: Addison Rae Found Catharsis on the Dance Floor With Her Live Debut of â€˜Addisonâ€™
Paragraphs: ['', '', '', '', '', 'Addison Rae lost herself and found herself again.', 'With the release of her highly anticipated debut album, we saw a rebirth right before our eyes. Rebirth, rebrand, reintroductionâ€”whatever you call itâ€”the Louisiana-born TikTok dancer transformed into one of the most promising pop acts of the current age with the release of â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ last summer. Since then, skeptics and day 1 superfans have tuned in to watch her every move, whether itâ€™s because of the push-and-pull of her hot girl next door persona or her slinky hooks and booming production from her collaborators, Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd.', 'So, when I got word that Addison and Spotify were hosting a rare live show on the eve of her album release, I knew I had to be there. Especially because it would technically be her first official live performance of tracks from her self-titled debut album.', 'She took center stage at New Yorkâ€™s famously sleazy and glamorous nightclub, The Box, which acted as her playground for the night. The room was filled to the brim with magazine editors, late-night producers, and devoted fans who waited hours for a glimpse of the star. Bushwickâ€™s elite even crossed the bridge to Manhattan to capture the newly minted pop princess in all her glory. As aerial artists and dancers donned lingerie underneath burning disco balls, I brushed shoulders with Addisonâ€™s star-studded stan list, from Julia Fox, Richie Shazam, and Amelia Gray to Conan Gray, Lola Tung, and Clairo.', 'The intimate inauguration marked a new beginning for Addison. As she opened her set with â€œFame Is a Gunâ€ in a kitschy satin bed, bated breaths escaped the lips of attendees who couldnâ€™t take their eyes off her.', 'The mic was on, and soon enough, she treated fans with her original cabaret-inspired â€œmusical theaterâ€ rendition of â€œHigh Fashion.â€ Her it girl-in-crime, Lexee Smith, served a campy, melodramatic poetry reading in Louboutins in between one of her outfit changes as a makeshift interlude until Addison returned for a particularly transcendental moment.', 'When the opening notes of â€œAquamarineâ€ trickled through The Boxâ€™s theater, not one word was missed by fans. I even overheard a friend over my shoulder say, â€œThis song is so gay.â€ (Complimentary. Not in the way that would prompt Hilary Duff to pull her allyship card.)', 'As Addison hit her marks in a flowy bright blue mini dress, we not only found catharsis on the dance floorâ€”she did, too.', 'In 2021, I covered the early days of Addisonâ€™s crossover from TikTok to real-world fame at Seventeen, and Iâ€™ll admit it: I was always intrigued by her essence, but I wasnâ€™t totally sold on â€œObsessedâ€ once it dropped.', 'It wasnâ€™t until one of my best friends dragged me to our living room to catch her performance on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon that I locked in and saw her for what she truly was: a small-town girl aching for the life of a big-city star. Let it be known that this was the moment she unlocked her potential as a Main Pop Girl in my eyes. From then on, I fully understood her vision. When most of her catalogue leaked in 2022, I clicked play for research purposes and fully became hooked by the following summer.', 'Before her 7-track performance last night, she teased what could come from the Addison Rae live experience, making cameos with her close friends and collaborators on multiple occasions. There was the â€œVon Dutchâ€ remix at Charli XCXâ€™s pre-brat Boiler Room set in Brooklyn and their post-brat performance on Coachellaâ€™s main stage, her â€œArcamarineâ€ stint during Arcaâ€™s more intimate set in the desert, and, of course, â€œDiet Pepsiâ€ with Charli and Troye Sivanâ€™s Sweat tour stop at Madison Square Garden. These moments inched us closer to the glittery dance pop world of Addison, yet we didnâ€™t see the star fully in her element. Title: Music Review: On Addison Raeâ€™s 'Addison,' a new pop powerhouse is born
Paragraphs: ['', '', '', '', 'This cover image released by Columbia Records shows "Addison" by Addison Rae.', '', 'NEW YORK (AP) â€” The pop album of the summer is here. Addison Raeâ€™s debut, â€œAddison,â€ is full, stuffed with bejeweled, hypnotic pop songs for the post-â€œBRATâ€ crowd. It was met with almost immediate backlash, as is common for young women with viral posts. But she wielded it like a weapon: Social media celebrity begat acting roles for Rae, then a coveted collaboration with Charli XCX in the form of a â€œVon Dutchâ€ remix, and now, at age 24, her final form: becoming the hyper-ambitious, hyper-femme pop star for the current moment.', 'As a full body of work, â€œAddisonâ€ taps into the genre-agnostic zeitgeist, where pop music appears edgy and elastic. The songs speak for themselves, from the pitch-shifted trip-hop â€œHeadphones Onâ€ and the snapped percussion, minor chords, NSFW lyrics and vanishing synths of â€œHigh Fashionâ€ to the Madonnaâ€œRay of Lightâ€-cosplay â€œAquamarineâ€ atop a house beat and its chantable, spoken chorus: â€œThe world is my oyster / Baby, come touch the pearl / The world is my oyster / And Iâ€™m the only girl.â€', 'Humor and girlhood are intertwined with less of a Sabrina Carpenter-wink and more of cheery irony. â€œMoney loves me,â€ she yells on â€œMoney Is Everything.â€ â€œIâ€™m the richest girl in the world!â€ Then, a giggle and a kiss. (â€œGirl,â€ to this writerâ€™s count, is uttered 20 times across the album. Across its 12 tracks, she is both the divine feminine and the girl next door. Often, they are one in the same.)', 'Rae isnâ€™t reinventing the wheel here, but she is carefully pulling from her inspirations. Her story recalls Britney Spears: The pair are from Louisiana, became famous young, and recorded their unique, sensual, layered pop music in Stockholm, Sweden, in and around super producer Max Martin. Thereâ€™s the earned Lana Del Rey parity, like in the â€œBorn to Dieâ€-channeling â€œDiet Pepsi,â€ echoes of Charli in the bouncy opener â€œNew York,â€ and tinges of ethereal Enya production on the dreamy â€œSummer Forever.â€', 'For â€œAddison,â€ Rae partnered with two primary collaborators â€“ Luka Kloser and Elvira AnderfjÃ¤rd, who goes simply by Elvira â€“ an unusually small team for a major label pop release. But that intimacy is one of the albumâ€™s superpowers, a sensibility that teeters between close mic recordings and big late-night anthems. In the latter case, look no further than â€œFame Is a Gun,â€ an easy song-of-the-summer contender, a sunglasses-in-the-club banger with synthetic vocal textures and an unignorable chorus.', 'In the lead up to the release of â€œAddison,â€ Rae has positioned her early TikTok fame as a means to an end.
